DROCHAID NA CAOIDH THE BRIDGE OF MOURNING DROCHAID NA CAOIDH
Faodaidh tu seasamh rè latha air Drochaid na Caoidh ag èisdeachd ri guileig a’ ghuilbnich ’s ri fuaim an uisge a’ cagair gu binn anns na linneachan: no faodaidh tu amharc air aodann nam mòr-bheann a tha ag èirigh air gach taobh den ghleann uaigneach anns an eilean air nach bi ainm. You may stand during a day on the Bridge of Mourning listening to the warbling of the curlews and to the sound of the water whispering sweetly in the pools: or you may behold the face of the great mountains that are rising on each side of the remote nameless glen on the island. Faodaidh tu seasamh rè latha air Drochaid na Caoidh ag èisdeachd ri guileig a’ ghuilbnich ’s ri fuaim an uisge a’ cagair gu binn anns na linneachan : no faodaidh tu amharc air aodann nam mòr - bheann a tha ag èirigh air gach taobh de n ghleann uaigneach anns an eilean air nach bi ainm .
Ach air ciaradh don fheasgar cha ghabh thu an rathad seo. But at evening twilight you will not take this road. Ach air ciaradh do n fheasgar cha ghabh thu an rathad seo .
Tha cagailtean càirdeil far an dèan iad do bheatha agus far am faod thu feitheamh ri èirigh na grèine. There are friendly hearths where they will make your life and where you may wait for sunrise. Tha cagailtean càirdeil far an dèan iad do bheatha agus far am faod thu feitheamh ri èirigh na grèine .
Gheibh thu fàilte ’s furan nan eilean — an spàin-adhairc agus an taobh as blàithe den teine. You will get a welcome and island hospitality – the horn spoon and the warmest side of the fire. Gheibh thu fàilte ’s furan nan eilean — an spàin - adhairc agus an taobh a s blàithe de n teine .
’S chan e guileag a’ ghuilbnich no cagar an uillt no osnadh nam beann a chuireas eagal ort, ach gaoir tiamhaidh mnà ’s i caoidh. And it is not the curlew’s warbling nor the whispering of the stream not the sighing of the mountains that will frighten you, but plaintive humming of a woman and her mourning. ’S chan e guileag a’ ghuilbnich no cagar an uillt no osnadh nam beann a chuireas eagal ort , ach gaoir tiamhaidh mnà ’s i
caoidh .
Nach iongnadh leat mar a nì mnathan caoidh airson a’ chealgair, an fhir-fhuadain, an duine gun stèidh, a chionn ’s gu bheil e flathail na phearsa, gaisgeil na ghiùlan, no theagamh deas gu bradan a thoirt à linne no ruaig a chur air an damh chròiceach. It will not surprise you how woman will mourn for the deceiver, the vagabond, the unprincipled man, because he is princely in his person, heroic in his conduct, or perhaps able to get a salmon from a pond or chase off the antlered stag. Nach iongnadh leat mar a nì mnathan caoidh air son a’ chealgair , an fhir - fhuadain , an duine gun stèidh , a chionn ’s gu bheil e flathail n a phearsa , gaisgeil n a ghiùlan , no theagamh deas gu bradan a thoirt à linne no ruaig a chur air an damh chròiceach .
Bha a’ cheart smuain aig Mòrag NicGilleathain ’s i na suidhe aig a gealbhan fhèin, a sùilean air toit na mòna bha ’g èirigh gu na tarsannan. Morag MacLean had the right thought as she was sat by her own hearth, her eyes on the peat smoke that was rising to the crossbeams. Bha a’ cheart smuain aig Mòrag NicGilleathain ’s i n a suidhe aig a gealbhan fhèin , a sùilean air toit na mòna
bha ’g èirigh gu na tarsannan .
Trì bliadhna on a thàinig crìoch air a’ chogadh san Fhraing, ach cha do thill Ailean, a cèile — Ailean a thilg uaith an corran airson a’ chlaidheimh — Ailean a’ chridhe aotroim, na coise siùbhlaich, ’s na sùla mireagaich daonnan ri spòrs. Three years since the war in France had ended, but Alan had not returned, her spouse – Alan who threw from her the sickle for the sword – Alan of the light heart, the speedy foot, and the mirthful eye always looking for fun. Trì bliadhna on a thàinig crìoch air a’ chogadh s an Fhraing , ach cha do thill Ailean , a cèile — Ailean a thilg uaith an corran air son a’ chlaidheimh — Ailean a’ chridhe aotroim , na coise siùbhlaich , ’s na sùla mireagaich daonnan ri spòrs .
B’e an aon àm nach b’fheàrr air gealladh na air dèanadas e oidhche gheamhraidh nuair thogadh e an fhiodhall bhàrr a’ bhalla ’s a chuireadh e air ghleus i, ’s a chluicheadh e seana phuirt nan eilean, fhad ’s a bhiodh Mòrag a’ snìomh ri taobh an teine. The one time ... better ... promise ... performance ... when he would lift the fiddle off the wall and he would put it in tune, and he would play old tunes of the islands, while Morag would be spinning beside the fire. B’ e an aon àm nach b’ fheàrr air gealladh na air dèanadas e oidhche gheamhraidh nuair
thogadh e an fhiodhall bhàrr a’ bhalla ’s a chuireadh e air ghleus i , ’s a chluicheadh e seana phuirt nan eilean , fhad ’s a bhiodh Mòrag a’ snìomh ri taobh an teine .
Ach cha do thill Ailean agus ’s ann air Mòraig ’s air Màiri, a nighean, a thuit obair na croite — Mòrag nan sùilean gorma air am biodh aoibh an còmhnaidh, agus Màiri le suaip ri h-athair na sùilean agus a chridhealas na nàdar. But Alan had not returned and it was on Morag and Mary, her daughter, that the croft work fell – Morag of the blue eyes which were always affable, and Mary with a faint resemblance to ger father in her eyes and his cheerfulness in her nature. Ach cha do thill Ailean agus ’s ann air Mòraig ’s air Màiri , a nighean , a thuit obair na croite — Mòrag nan sùilean gorma air am biodh aoibh an còmhnaidh , agus Màiri le suaip ri
h-athair n a sùilean agus a chridhealas n a nàdar .
Fad làithean goirid a’ gheamhraidh ghiùlain iad an fheamainn an craileagan don chroit agus san oidhche, ri solas a’ chrùisgein, bha iad ri càrdadh ’s ri snìomh. During the short days of the winter they carried the seaweed in wool baskets to the croft and at night, bu the light of the oil-lamp, they were carding and spinning. Fad làithean goirid a’ gheamhraidh ghiùlain iad an fheamainn an craileagan do n chroit agus s an oidhche , ri solas a’ chrùisgein , bha iad ri càrdadh ’s ri snìomh .
San earrach thionndaidh iad am fearann leis a’ chois-chruim agus gheàrr iad mòine sa’ bhlàr. In the spring they turned the ground with the foot plough and they cut peat in the field. S an earrach thionndaidh iad am fearann leis a’ chois - chruim agus gheàrr iad mòine s a’ bhlàr .
Air feasgar aig deireadh an fhoghair, bha Mòrag na suidhe ri taobh an teine, sgìth le saothair an latha, ’s i beachdachadh air làithean a bha seachad ’s air bliadhnachan a bha ri teachd. On an evening at the end of autumn, Morag was dsat beside the fire, tired with the day’s labour, thinking about days that were past and about years that were to come. seòladh , a’ seòladh , ’ ach dh’fhaoidte gun till e fhathast mun tig sneachd a’ gheamhraidh . ”
Mo lèireadh! My torment! Mo lèireadh !

Even though the snow came, Alan did not come, but news was heard from a Lowland drover that Alan had played the last tune. Ged a thàinig an sneachd , cha tàinig Ailean , ach ’s e
chualas naidheachd dhròbhair Ghallda gun chluich Ailean am port mu dheireadh .

“Bha sin an dèidh do dh’Ailean togail air don Fhraing le òrain ’s le chlaidheamh.” “That was after Alan taking himself off to France with songs and with a sword.” “ Bha sin an dèidh do dh’Ailean togail air do n Fhraing le òrain ’s le chlaidheamh . ”

But that would be how it was, at the start of spring, Donald MacPhail declared the love that was in his heart, and Morag made listening when he whispered the words in her ear. She forgot Alan of the light tune, and there was no memory of him but the painful work and the long lonely years that would be before her all by herself. That was the wedding that Morag and Mary had in Kilfinnan church, and an memorable party in the big barn of Killeran. B’ i sin a’ bhanais a bh’ aig Mòrag ’s aig Màiri ann an eaglais Chill - fhianain , agus cuirm nach robh a leithid ann an sabhal mòr Chill - Eadhrain .

And even though they were from all corners of the island, there was nobody there quite like Donald MacPhail, unless it was Alexander Campbell himself. ’S ged a bha iad às gach ceàrn de n eilean , cha robh ann leithid Dhòmhnaill MhicPhàil mur b’ e Alasdair Caimbeul fhèin .
’S mur b’ann aig Màiri cha b’ann aig t’èile bha sùil no cas a dhannsadh cho sunndach ri feadhainn Mòraig. And unless it were Mary’s it was no other woman’s that there was no eye nor foot that would dance as merrily as some of Morag’s. ’S mur b’ ann aig Màiri cha b’ ann aig t’ èile bha sùil no cas a dhannsadh cho sunndach ri feadhainn Mòraig .
